title: A Request for Some Information About the 'Heart of the City II' Project

content:
Dear Albert Thwiepp,
Thank you for your request for information relating to Heart of the City 2
which we received on 22/09/2024.
This has been logged as a Freedom of Information Request and will be dealt
with under the Freedom of Information Act 2000. The reference number for
your request can be found above.
The Freedom of Information Act 2000 states that we must respond to you
within 20 working days, by 18/10/2024. Please do not hesitate to contact
us at the email address below if you have any queries.
Yours sincerely,
Sheffield City Council
PO Box 1283
Sheffield, S1 1UJ

Dear Albert Thwiepp,
Thank you for your request for information relating to Heart of the City 2
which we received on 22/09/2024.
Please find Sheffield City Council’s response to your request set out
below:
The numbers of let and vacant street level units; The numbers of vacant
and let non-street level, non-residential units; The total floor areas of
the let and vacant units referred to above; The terms of any rental
incentives (without any names of tenants) offered to potential and current
occupiers of street level units;
The numbers of let and vacant residential units constructed as part of
this scheme.
It is not possible to provide a figure only for street level units as some
units such as Leah’s Yard and Cambridge Street Collective are let as whole
units including upper floors.  These are therefore included in the totals
below as are Bethel Chapel and the Sunday School which will also be let in
this way:
There are a total of 46 units to let.  Of these 19 are let, 5 are under
offer and 21 remain unlet.
In terms of floorspace, there is a total of 20,670sqm, of which 10,670 sqm
is let (53%), 3,124sqm (16%) is under offer and 6,300 (31%) remain unlet.
For the non-Street Level, non residential units, again given the nature of
some of the units above that are let or will be let as whole units at
street level and above the figures below relate to office space on upper
floors.  These aren’t units as they relate to multiple floors that could
be subdivided so only the amount of floorspace let,  and unlet is
provided.
In total, there is 37,614 sqm of lettable “upper” floor space, of which
30,643 (81%) is let,  and 7,151 sq m is unlet (19%)
There are 52 apartments and 4 townhouses developed for sale.  Of these all
the apartments have been sold and one of the four town houses have been
sold.
In addition, Kangaroo Works was a site in the Heart of the City
development that was sold to a developer to build 364 one, two and three
bedroom apartments for rent.  The development completed in November 2023.
According to the website
[1]
https://www.ilivearound.com/sheffield/ka...
there are 8
apartments available to rent.
At end of the last complete financial year:
The total expenditure from all sources to complete the HoS2 scheme; The
total debt incurred by SCC to enable the scheme's completion; The term and
interest rate of any debt specifically associated with HoS2 whether
secured on it or not.
At the end of the last complete financial year,
Total forecast outturn: £376.8m
Funded from:
Prudential Borrowing: £341.0m
Capital receipts: £15.6m
Grants and other contributions: £20.2m
There is no debt specifically associated with the HOCII scheme as the
Council finances the Capital financing requirement as a whole, loans are
not specifically allocated to Capital Projects.
If you have any queries about this response, please do not hesitate to
contact us.
The information provided in this response is available for re-use under
the terms of the Open Government Licence v3.0. The terms of the OGL can be
found [2]here. When re-using the information, Sheffield City Council
requires you to include the following attribution statement: “Contains
public sector information obtained from Sheffield City Council and
licensed under the Open Government Licence v3.0.”
If you are unhappy with the response you have received in relation to your
request, you are entitled to have this reviewed. You can ask for an
internal review by replying to this email. Internal review requests should
be submitted within 40 working days from the date of this response.
If you remain dissatisfied with the outcome of your internal review, you
can contact the Information Commissioner’s Office. Please see
[3]
https://ico.org.uk/make-a-complaint/offi...
for further details.
Kind Regards,
Sheffield City Council
PO Box 1283
Sheffield, S1 1UJ
